awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: MRA: Quantifying phenological coherence and seasonal predictability across NEON and USA-NPN monitoring sites
awd_abstract_narration:
The seasonal timing, or phenology, of many North American plant species is in flux with accelerating environmental change. The influence of factors such as temperature and precipitation on plant growth, as weather patterns change from spring to summer, vary from place-to-place, month-to-month, and for different plant species. An improved understanding of these relationships revealed by this research will support development of more accurate and diverse models of spring plant growth stages. These models may then be able to predict which trees and shrubs will be favored in different regions with future environmental change, to the benefit of many types of societal planning. Further, the project will implement national-scale, long-lead forecasts for new measures representing the spring season, which will also be relevant for annual agricultural, horticultural, and forestry management planning.  Additional broader impacts of this research include: (1) developing junior high school materials and programming for students to engage with phenological observations and real-time weather data; and (2) enlisting tens of thousands of non-scientist volunteer observers to broaden participation in citizen science spring phenology data collection campaigns through the USA-National Phenology Network (NPN) Nature’s Notebook program.

This research is guided by three fundamental questions that span spatial and temporal scales: (1) Which species exhibit variation in phenological response across latitude, elevation, or other gradients? (2) Does the influence of variables that drive phenological events (such as accumulated warmth and light intensity) increase or decrease as the season progresses, and does this vary geographically, with the onset of spring’s progression poleward and upslope? (3) At what lead times (days, weeks, months, or seasons) can climate forecasts reliably predict phenological behavior at monitoring sites? By combining recently developed state-of-the-art weather and climate forecasts and robust statistical post-processing techniques with rich ground-based phenological data resources from the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) and other large-scale networks, this project will: (1) develop and refine models of spring plant phenological activity for dozens of species; (2) evaluate the influence of changes in climate driver variables over the course of the spring season—resulting from changes in the structure of large-scale circulation patterns—on predicting phenological events; (3) determine which species exhibit varying phenological response across spatial gradients, and therefore should be accounted for in predictive models; and (4) assess the potential predictability of those models on seasonal to decadal time horizons to operationalize long-term forecasting by the USA-NPN. Finally, research knowledge gained from this project will provide valuable insights toward enhanced understanding of the much more challenging plant-climate interactions in autumn.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Plants and animals time their seasonal activities like flowering, leaf-out, and migration based on environmental cues, particularly temperature. As climate change affects these cues, understanding how different species respond becomes increasingly important. This project developed new tools to track and predict spring's arrival across the United States, helping everyone from farmers to wildlife managers better prepare for seasonal changes.

We developed a suite of new "Spring Development Indices" that expand upon existing tools by incorporating observations from thousands of volunteer scientists across the country. Unlike previous indices that used only a few specially cultivated plants, our new approach includes many natural species, accounting for how plants adapt differently across their geographic ranges. This makes our predictions more relevant for local conditions while maintaining accuracy across the continent.

Our research revealed several key findings:

1) Different species show varying sensitivities to temperature changes, with some advancing their spring activities by up to 9 days for each degree Celsius of warming

2) Non-native plants generally respond more strongly to temperature changes than native species

3) Earlier-active species tend to be more sensitive to temperature changes

4) Shrubs often show stronger responses than trees

5) Plants at higher latitudes exhibit a larger shift in the timing of flowering than those at lower latitudes, demonstrating that changes in phenology vary across species' ranges

We also developed an operational forecasting system to extend the time horizons used in the USA-NPN’s annual "Springcasting!" campaign.  This system is now available online and data can be integrated into other third party websites or tools, helping the public track spring's progression in real-time. As well, the USA National Phenology Network (USA-NPN) team will offer enhanced and new maps indicating how spring is unfolding in real time across the country.  These new map products will be available as image and raster files through the USA-NPN website and data access tools and will be used in communication with the news media and the general public.

The project provided valuable training opportunities for early career scientists and established writing workshops that helped researchers better communicate their findings. We engaged with teachers and students through workshops and school visits, creating educational resources about climate change and seasonal timing. Our work with the Museum of the Earth in Ithaca, NY, helped bring these concepts to the public through hands-on activities and exhibitions.

Key products from this project include:

1) New models for predicting spring arrival across the United States

2) Novel datasets at high spatial resolution indicating historical and real-time patterns in the timing of spring plant activity across the conterminous U.S.

3) Online tools for tracking seasonal changes

4) Educational resources for teachers and students

5) Interpretive information available for the general public and the news media

6) Published research advancing our understanding of how plants respond to climate change

This work helps communities better prepare for and adapt to changing seasonal patterns, whether they're planning agricultural activities, managing natural resources, or dealing with seasonal allergies. As climate change continues to affect seasonal timing, these tools and insights become increasingly valuable for both scientific understanding and practical decision-making.
